author: g11tech
content: <@211091239112671234> I have a Q, when we sync range lets say account range, and there is no data between origin and limit, would the proofs returned will have proof of absence for both origin and limit?

author: g11tech
content: and if there is not sufficient data between origin and limit (i.e. bytes is big enough), then proof of absense of limit will be there? (lets say limit key doesn't exist in the state)

author: g11tech
content:
basically this is what the spec says: ```
The responding node is allowed to return less data than requested (own QoS limits), but the node must return at least one account. If no accounts exist between startingHash and limitHash, then the first (if any) account after limitHash must be provided.
```

author: g11tech
content: Doubt 1 ) so if there is no data between `startingHash` and `limitHash`, then it should give an account after `limitHash` + as well as proof of absense for `startingHash` ?  (assuming `startingHash` is not in the state)

author: g11tech
content: Doubt 2) If there is no data on/after `startingHash` i.e. last account in the state was before `startingHash`, we would get a proof of absense for `startingHash` as well as `limitHash`?

author: g11tech
content: Basically spec (https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/caps/snap.md) doesn't talk about proof of non existence for `limitHash`
